Input.posts:
Professor, In one of the Meno, lectures, you posed the question of whether Socrates was 'messing with Meno' in terms of Socrates' belief in the reincarnation of the soul. You seemed to imply that at one point you thought Socrates/Plato was being sincere with this belief (in your book), but you may have changed your mind now. Why? From reading several other dialogues, it seems to me that Socrates/Plato's belief in reincarnation (metempsychosis) was sincere. Apart from several mentions of it in Phadrus, Republic Book 10, and Meno, which uses the transmigration of the soul as a metaphorical point to underscore his ideas, but they also seem to support a sincere belief in transmigration. Additionally, Socrates/Plato's recollection theory of knowledge seems to hinge on metempsychosis, rather than intuitionism. Finally, in Phaedo Socrates discusses the transmigration of the soul in terms of the recollection theory of knowledge, as well as connecting the soul to the Forms (I'm wording this poorly: forgive me, I'm tired) in order to prove that the soul is immortal. I feel that if he uses transmigration to prove the immortality of the soul in the Phaedo, arguably one of the most important topics of discussion for Socrates (the whole point of philosophy being to prepare the soul to die), it seems that he takes the idea of transmigration seriously. I may be missing something: I've read about half of Plato's dialogues and this is the impression I am getting, but of course I need to finish the rest in order to determine whether Plato/Socrates refutes transmigration in other dialogues. What do you think? Thank you for your time.

Hi Heather, To read his dialogue where he discusses reincarnation, I would refer you to Phaedo. It isn't long and is an excellent dialogue. He is about to drink the poison hemlock as his death sentence, and his friends are worried for him because they don't believe the soul is immortal. The purpose of the dialogue is for Socrates to prove that the soul is immortal. He believes in reincarnation because it supports his theory of knowledge and learning. There are two ways we can learn: experientially and abstractly. Abstract learning comes from reason, which reaches to a higher plane. Since this is non-experiential (but deductive or intuitive), his recollection theory of knowledge is that the only kind of knowledge is experiential, but that we have forgotten our experiences. Our ability to comprehend and reason about the ultimate, Forms, and universal ideas comes from our experiences of these forms while we were a disembodied soul (his mythos about this is more apparent in his dialogue Phaedrus, also a great dialogue). However, before we are born we forget that we have this knowledge (souls drink from the waters of oblivion, see the myth at the end of Republic Book X), but we can regain it through the diligent practice of philosophy and, specifically, dialectic. Hence, our learning of abstract universal truths are not actually learnings, but recollections of our experiences of them when we lived on the aetherial plane of Forms (he also has another proof of the immortality of the soul by claiming it is the Form of life, and Forms are indestructable). The reason why we reincarnate is, similar to Hinduism and Buddhism, because we are locked in a materialistically dependent cycle. For Socrates, however, this cycle is broken by the constant practice of the soul to looking towards the Good, The Beautiful, and all other Forms. In our life, if we constantly strive to direct our soul and thoughts towards Truth, then our soul will be less bound to the material world and, when we die, it will detach itself from the cycle of rebirth and return to the world of Forms. If we disregard Truth, when we die our souls will also be attached to material things so that it is reborn. Interestingly, Socrates claims in Republic X that the soul itself chooses its own next life if it has to reincarnate. So if the soul was good and wise, but not truly philosophical, it would choose a life for itself that would help it strive closer to the Good. However, if the soul was foolish, it would choose a life that distances itself from the Good and instead strives for material goods (this soul would choose the life of a tyrant, for example). I personally like this last idea, I think its an interesting take on reincarnating into better/worse castes or animals. I hope I have done justice to Socrates' theory, but I know I've missed a lot and may even be slightly wrong in some places. All the more reason to read the dialogues instead of taking it from me! The Phaedrus mythos and the Republic Book X mythos are particularly rich, and although I believe that he is sincere in his beliefs in reincarnation, these myths are rich in metaphor and symbolism and are just an elevating thing to read, regardless of personal beliefs (I don't believe in reincarnation either). Hope this helped!

Hence, our learning of abstract universal truths are not actually learnings, but recollections of our experiences of them when we lived on the aetherial plane of Forms (he also has another proof of the immortality of the soul by claiming it is the Form of life, and Forms are indestructable). He is about to drink the poison hemlock as his death sentence, and his friends are worried for him because they don't believe the soul is immortal. The purpose of the dialogue is for Socrates to prove that the soul is immortal. He believes in reincarnation because it supports his theory of knowledge and learning. There are two ways we can learn: experientially and abstractly. Abstract learning comes from reason, which reaches to a higher plane. Since this is non-experiential (but deductive or intuitive), his recollection theory of knowledge is that the only kind of knowledge is experiential, but that we have forgotten our experiences. Our ability to comprehend and reason about the ultimate, Forms, and universal ideas comes from our experiences of these forms while we were a disembodied soul (his mythos about this is more apparent in his dialogue Phaedrus, also a great dialogue). However, before we are born we forget that we have this knowledge (souls drink from the waters of oblivion, see the myth at the end of Republic Book X), but we can regain it through the diligent practice of philosophy and, specifically, dialectic. Hence, our learning of abstract universal truths are not actually learnings, but recollections of our experiences of them when we lived on the aetherial plane of Forms (he also has another proof of the immortality of the soul by claiming it is the Form of life, and Forms are indestructable). The reason why we reincarnate is, similar to Hinduism and Buddhism, because we are locked in a materialistically dependent cycle. For Socrates, however, this cycle is broken by the constant practice of the soul to looking towards the Good, The Beautiful, and all other Forms. In our life, if we constantly strive to direct our soul and thoughts towards Truth, then our soul will be less bound to the material world and, when we die, it will detach itself from the cycle of rebirth and return to the world of Forms. The purpose of the dialogue is for Socrates to prove that the soul is immortal. He believes in reincarnation because it supports his theory of knowledge and learning. There are two ways we can learn: experientially and abstractly. Abstract learning comes from reason, which reaches to a higher plane. Since this is non-experiential (but deductive or intuitive), his recollection theory of knowledge is that the only kind of knowledge is experiential, but that we have forgotten our experiences. Our ability to comprehend and reason about the ultimate, Forms, and universal ideas comes from our experiences of these forms while we were a disembodied soul (his mythos about this is more apparent in his dialogue Phaedrus, also a great dialogue). However, before we are born we forget that we have this knowledge (souls drink from the waters of oblivion, see the myth at the end of Republic Book X), but we can regain it through the diligent practice of philosophy and, specifically, dialectic. Hence, our learning of abstract universal truths are not actually learnings, but recollections of our experiences of them when we lived on the aetherial plane of Forms (he also has another proof of the immortality of the soul by claiming it is the Form of life, and Forms are indestructable). The reason why we reincarnate is, similar to Hinduism and Buddhism, because we are locked in a materialistically dependent cycle. For Socrates, however, this cycle is broken by the constant practice of the soul to looking towards the Good, The Beautiful, and all other Forms. In our life, if we constantly strive to direct our soul and thoughts towards Truth, then our soul will be less bound to the material world and, when we die, it will detach itself from the cycle of rebirth and return to the world of Forms. If we disregard Truth, when we die our souls will also be attached to material things so that it is reborn. Interestingly, Socrates claims in Republic X that the soul itself chooses its own next life if it has to reincarnate. So if the soul was good and wise, but not truly philosophical, it would choose a life for itself that would help it strive closer to the Good. However, if the soul was foolish, it would choose a life that distances itself from the Good and instead strives for material goods (this soul would choose the life of a tyrant, for example). I personally like this last idea, I think its an interesting take on reincarnating into better/worse castes or animals. I hope I have done justice to Socrates' theory, but I know I've missed a lot and may even be slightly wrong in some places. All the more reason to read the dialogues instead of taking it from me! The Phaedrus mythos and the Republic Book X mythos are particularly rich, and although I believe that he is sincere in his beliefs in reincarnation, these myths are rich in metaphor and symbolism and are just an elevating thing to read, regardless of personal beliefs (I don't believe in reincarnation either). Hope this helped!

At the risk of making myself unpopular, I'd like to complain about how too many of the discussions are going. It's making me quite discouraged about looking at the forums. Surely that's the first step in engaging with Plato, to grasp his arguments fully?Instead, I often see the discussion either pretty much ignore the arguments in the text, or brush over them quickly, then veer away and move briskly on to the expression of a student's opinion on something, sometimes in support of a character in the dialogue, sometimes quite tangential to the text (I won't even mention the example of the thread in which a couple of people get silly and use vulgar.language--I fled immediately). Input.posts:
On at least two occasions, prof Holbo suggests that we today can't really be more morally capable than our Socratic ancestors, yet Socrates' contemporaries were owning slaves. Therefore we should wonder whether slavery is right or wrong. Interesting, perhaps, and, today, easily answered by most, the answer relies on a few basic assumptions, different now from classical times, which is exactly why we, today, are indeed running, as Holbo puts it, different software on what, presumably, is the same hardware. Though, whether we run version 2.0 or, to stay within the analogy, a completely different package or operating system, is not evident. Besides that, in exerting control, many individuals will prefer to try and gain more control over their fellow man, we, as a species, now, do mostly subscribe to the ideal that we are all born equal and should be treated equally in similar circumstances. We accept this to be true. Clearly, and very obviously, the ancient Greeks did not. Whether this is, on some undefined absolute scale, more right or not, is not really directly relevant. It simply is what we've agreed upon. Sure, you can argue that abolishing of slavery is a perverse act of self preservation (if slavery is illegal, you nor your ancestors can ever become slaves), but this is not really relevant. We now agree on different rules for the game of life, resulting in different consequences. That is all.

Cannot agree with the conclusion of Lesson 6 part 1 lecture: i.e. Deioces is a supervillain with the superpower of justice because his motives were suspect. Why? Because no villain practices justice as his daily craft - if he did then he would no longer be a supervillain. Looking at this another way - would a superhero (regardless of motive) practising injustice, daily, be a still considered a superhero - No! he would be re-graded as a supervillain!

Input.threadtitle: Was anyone else horrified by this utopia?
Input.posts:
I was listening to the audiobook of the republic, book 2 I believe, and I had to stop in the middle because it completely freaked me out. I've lived in Plato's proposed state. It's where poets and writers are censored and punished for supposedly 'lying' about history and God, where individual lives have almost no importance compared to the 'common good', where 'morality' and the 'ideals' are defined by a pious philosopher who sees 'the light' and are protected by the guardians of the state, where women are treated as second class citizens and generally kept out of public life (as well as what he calls 'the lesser men'), where being a man means not expressing your emotions (and bottling it up against your nature and eventually exploding in violence), where dying for the cause of the state implies living happily forever (so young men can get themselves killed in wars easily for the sake of 'the common good'). It's called The Islamic Republic of Iran (in case it wasn't clear, it's not a great place to live). That was a big surprise for me to see how meticulously plato details the specific aspects of information that needs to be controlled and how gods and ideals (and even masculinity) need to be defined in order to control people's lives. And how convenient that the rulers are philosophers! I don't know, maybe I'm being harsh to someone who lived thousands of years ago and they hadn't seen how quickly (and predictably) such a state turns into tyranny. But on the other hand, he is not a regular guy from 400 BC. He knew quite a lot about human nature, to a point that we can still learn from him thousands of years later. Can we really assume he couldn't imagine the issues with this paradise? If so, how come? Is it because of something he wanted badly, that blinded him? I couldn't finish the books, I probably should, but the dialogue format makes it even more uncomfortable to read. He is arguing in cold blood against basic human rights, and his friends cheer him on.
Upvotes:
3
I think we should read more of this and reserve our judgement till we understand the bigger picture. But yes, my initial thoughts are that I think Plato takes takes his fundamental Socrates premise of Specialisation to the extreme and this is causing this problem. He divides the city people into Philosophers, Guardians and Producers and the basis of this division is the inherent qualities in man. People of reason, spirit and appetite as he calls it. There is some merit in this argument - some people are more suited to certain kinds of jobs. So he allocates responsibilities in society on this basis. And then all follows to keep this infact - education, exposure, poetry, art etc. While this sort of â€˜Specializationâ€™ has its benefits, it is very simplistic as no society call be established at the cost of individual freedom. Suppression of individual rights even if intended for the overall societal good, gives rise to a whole lot of inequalities and problems. And the irony is that the system that evolves out of this in the long run can hardly be called just, which has been the objective all along ! India has been through a similar sort of class system in the past and we have learnt that the evils outweigh the benefits.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Being horrified by Plato's Republic (as opposed to Plato's Republic ) is, in fact, a common and, I think, basically correct response. Probably the most famous book that puts the response into words is Karl Popper's The Open Society and Its Enemies . One thing I would keep in mind is that Plato may not be serious about a lot of this. I don't say that to get him off the hook but because I think it's likely to be true, at least sometimes. (I'm not sure whether it does get him off the hook if he's joking. But we ought to consider whether he might be.) As to the predictability of totalitarian disasters: it is worth considering that Plato was recoiling from Athenian democracy, which was not just a kind of radical democracy but radically unprofessional - un-technocratic, by modern standards. If you life in a society in which people are literally chosen by lot for important public positions, it's not hard to see how you might recoil, like so: we could use more expertise around the place. The world of modern totalitarianism gone wrong is far from his experience, even if he did know about conditions in Sparta ... I don't think it's so unlikely that he did miss the dangers of totalitarianism through his desire - as a member of the aristocracy - to institute proper aristocracy. This is rather a harsh truth about Plato. But it's considerably complicated by the persistent centrality of Socrates in all these dialogues. Socrates is hardly built along the lines of Lenin, let alone Hitler. I think it's fair to say that Plato is always maintaining a kind of counterpoint between a mood of rationalist control and one of Socratic freedom. In the end, it doesn't make sense to say he's just a fascist - because he's going to ban the poets! - any more than it makes sense to deny he's disturbingly authoritarian - because Socrates! It's all in there. Which is weird. He blueprinted the first totalitarian utopia. And he wrote 'Apology', which is an eloquent defense of individual conscience and free inquiry. He's weirdly modern, in good and bad ways.

Input.threadtitle: Was anyone else horrified by this utopia?
Input.posts:
I was listening to the audiobook of the republic, book 2 I believe, and I had to stop in the middle because it completely freaked me out. I've lived in Plato's proposed state. It's where poets and writers are censored and punished for supposedly 'lying' about history and God, where individual lives have almost no importance compared to the 'common good', where 'morality' and the 'ideals' are defined by a pious philosopher who sees 'the light' and are protected by the guardians of the state, where women are treated as second class citizens and generally kept out of public life (as well as what he calls 'the lesser men'), where being a man means not expressing your emotions (and bottling it up against your nature and eventually exploding in violence), where dying for the cause of the state implies living happily forever (so young men can get themselves killed in wars easily for the sake of 'the common good'). It's called The Islamic Republic of Iran (in case it wasn't clear, it's not a great place to live). That was a big surprise for me to see how meticulously plato details the specific aspects of information that needs to be controlled and how gods and ideals (and even masculinity) need to be defined in order to control people's lives. And how convenient that the rulers are philosophers! I don't know, maybe I'm being harsh to someone who lived thousands of years ago and they hadn't seen how quickly (and predictably) such a state turns into tyranny. But on the other hand, he is not a regular guy from 400 BC. He knew quite a lot about human nature, to a point that we can still learn from him thousands of years later. Can we really assume he couldn't imagine the issues with this paradise? If so, how come? Is it because of something he wanted badly, that blinded him? I couldn't finish the books, I probably should, but the dialogue format makes it even more uncomfortable to read. He is arguing in cold blood against basic human rights, and his friends cheer him on.

I think we should read more of this and reserve our judgement till we understand the bigger picture. But yes, my initial thoughts are that I think Plato takes takes his fundamental Socrates premise of Specialisation to the extreme and this is causing this problem. He divides the city people into Philosophers, Guardians and Producers and the basis of this division is the inherent qualities in man. People of reason, spirit and appetite as he calls it. There is some merit in this argument - some people are more suited to certain kinds of jobs. So he allocates responsibilities in society on this basis. And then all follows to keep this infact - education, exposure, poetry, art etc. While this sort of â€˜Specializationâ€™ has its benefits, it is very simplistic as no society call be established at the cost of individual freedom. Suppression of individual rights even if intended for the overall societal good, gives rise to a whole lot of inequalities and problems. And the irony is that the system that evolves out of this in the long run can hardly be called just, which has been the objective all along ! India has been through a similar sort of class system in the past and we have learnt that the evils outweigh the benefits.

Instructor's Post
Being horrified by Plato's Republic (as opposed to Plato's Republic ) is, in fact, a common and, I think, basically correct response. Probably the most famous book that puts the response into words is Karl Popper's The Open Society and Its Enemies . One thing I would keep in mind is that Plato may not be serious about a lot of this. I don't say that to get him off the hook but because I think it's likely to be true, at least sometimes. (I'm not sure whether it does get him off the hook if he's joking. But we ought to consider whether he might be.) As to the predictability of totalitarian disasters: it is worth considering that Plato was recoiling from Athenian democracy, which was not just a kind of radical democracy but radically unprofessional - un-technocratic, by modern standards. If you life in a society in which people are literally chosen by lot for important public positions, it's not hard to see how you might recoil, like so: we could use more expertise around the place. The world of modern totalitarianism gone wrong is far from his experience, even if he did know about conditions in Sparta ... I don't think it's so unlikely that he did miss the dangers of totalitarianism through his desire - as a member of the aristocracy - to institute proper aristocracy. This is rather a harsh truth about Plato. But it's considerably complicated by the persistent centrality of Socrates in all these dialogues. Socrates is hardly built along the lines of Lenin, let alone Hitler. I think it's fair to say that Plato is always maintaining a kind of counterpoint between a mood of rationalist control and one of Socratic freedom. In the end, it doesn't make sense to say he's just a fascist - because he's going to ban the poets! - any more than it makes sense to deny he's disturbingly authoritarian - because Socrates! It's all in there. Which is weird. He blueprinted the first totalitarian utopia. And he wrote 'Apology', which is an eloquent defense of individual conscience and free inquiry. He's weirdly modern, in good and bad ways.
